tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving bending stress due to wind pressure and yield strength. It requires multiple steps to calculate the bending moment and then relate it to the dimensions of the hollow square pole. It integrates concepts from mechanics of materials and fluid mechanics.

answer_validation.reasoning: Based on the given information and applying the relevant principles of structural mechanics, the minimum required dimension 'd' of the pole's square cross-section to sustain the 7.5 kPa wind pressure is calculated to be in the range of 232 to 238 mm. This satisfies both the allowable bending stress and allowable shear stress criteria for the pole material with a yield strength of 240 MPa.

step_by_step: Identify the key given information: Signboard size (3 m x 1 m), pole cross-section outer dimension (250 mm), wind pressure (7.5 kPa), and yield strength of pole material (240 MPa).
Determine the wind force (P) acting on the signboard: P = q * A = 7.5 kPa * (3 m * 1 m) = 22.5 kN.
Calculate the bending moment (M) at the base of the pole: M = P * L_b = 22.5 kN * (3.2 m + 0.75 m/2) = 76.875 kNm.
Calculate the maximum bending stress (σ_b) using the formula: σ_b = (M * r_outer) / I, where r_outer = d/2 and I = (π * d^4) / 64.
Set the bending stress equal to the allowable stress (σ_allow = 240 MPa) and solve for the minimum required dimension 'd'.
Also check the maximum shear stress (τ_max) using the formula: τ_max = (4/3) * (V / A_net), where V = P = 22.5 kN and A_net = (π * d^2) / 4.
Set the shear stress equal to the allowable shear stress (τ_allow = 240 MPa / √3) and solve for the minimum 'd'.
The larger of the two 'd' values calculated from bending and shear is the critical dimension that satisfies both failure criteria.

difficulty_factors: Requires understanding of how wind load is converted into bending, torsion, and shear
Involves setting up and solving coupled equations for bending and shear stresses

textbook_references.author: Beer & Johnston
textbook_references.chapter_title: Analysis and Design of Beams for Bending, Shearing Stresses in Beams
textbook_references.text_snippet: Formulas for bending stress, shear stress, and stress transformation in beams.

textbook_references.author: Megson, T.H.G.
textbook_references.text_snippet: Detailed analysis of combined bending, torsion, and shear in structural members.

video_references.topic_covered: Combined Stresses in Beams and Shafts

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Wind Load → Bending Moment & Shear Force → Bending Stress & Shear Stress → Minimum Dimension
key_insights: The base of the cantilever pole is the critical section for maximum moments and shear forces.
Points on the outer surface experience maximum bending and torsional shear, while points on the neutral axis experience maximum transverse shear and torsional shear.
The larger of the minimum dimensions calculated from bending and shear criteria is the critical dimension that must be used.

formulas_principles.name: Wind Force on Signboard
formulas_principles.conditions: Where q is the wind pressure and A is the signboard area
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula for calculating the wind load

formulas_principles.name: Bending Moment at Pole Base
formulas_principles.conditions: Where L_b is the bending arm length

formulas_principles.name: Maximum Shear Stress
formulas_principles.conditions: For a hollow square section, $A_\text{net} = \frac{\pi * d^2}{4}$

industry_examples: Design of signage support structures in highways and public spaces
Analysis of wind load on communication towers and power transmission line towers
specific_systems: Overhead variable message signs on highways
Cellular network towers in rural areas
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Ensuring the structural integrity and safety of infrastructure supporting large signage or equipment under wind loads is critical for public safety and reliable operation.

common_mistakes.mistake: Neglecting the effect of torsion when calculating stresses
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Focusing only on bending and shear without recognizing the significant torsional moment due to the eccentric wind load
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully consider all stress resultants (bending, torsion, shear) when dealing with eccentric loading on a structural member

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrectly calculating the polar moment of inertia (J) for the hollow square cross-section
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Unfamiliarity with the formula for composite/hollow sections or confusing it with the area moment of inertia (I)
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Review the formulas for geometric properties of hollow and composite sections, and clearly distinguish between I and J

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to check both bending and shear stress criteria to determine the critical dimension
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Focusing on only one failure mode without verifying the other
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always consider all relevant stress components (normal, shear) and compare to their respective allowable values to find the governing design criterion

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remember the four main stress resultants to consider in this type of combined loading problem
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When analyzing structures under eccentric loads

flashcards.front: What are the four main stress resultants to consider when analyzing a structure under eccentric loading?
flashcards.back: The four main stress resultants are: Bending, Eccentric loading, Shear, and Torsion (BEST).

flashcards.front: Write the formula for the polar moment of inertia (J) of a hollow circular shaft.
flashcards.back: $J = \frac{\pi}{32} \left(D_o^4 - D_i^4\right)$, where $D_o$ is the outer diameter and $D_i$ is the inner diameter.

flashcards.front: Explain why a hollow shaft is more efficient than a solid shaft for resisting torsion.
flashcards.back: A hollow shaft is more efficient because the material near the outer surface contributes more to the polar moment of inertia (J) than the material near the center. This allows a hollow shaft to have a higher torsional stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio compared to a solid shaft of the same outer diameter.

real_world_context.industry_example: Overhead variable message signs on highways are often supported by hollow steel poles that must withstand high wind loads. The poles are designed to have the minimum required diameter to meet both bending and shear stress criteria.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Ensuring the structural integrity of these signage supports is crucial for public safety, as a failure could lead to the sign collapsing and causing damage or injury.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quickly identify the key information (signboard size, wind pressure, material properties) and set up the bending moment, shear force, and stress calculations. This is a straightforward application of structural mechanics principles.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure of the exact dimension, provide a range that satisfies both the bending and shear stress criteria based on the given information.

search_keywords: strength of materials hollow section properties
GATE aerospace structures wind load problems
civil engineering design of highway signage

alternative_methods.name: Finite Element Analysis (FEA)
alternative_methods.description: Instead of the analytical approach using simplified formulas, the problem could be solved using FEA software that can model the complex 3D stress state in the pole under the eccentric wind load more accurately.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Can capture stress concentrations, non-linear effects, and complex geometries. Cons: Requires more computational effort and expertise in FEA modeling.

connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: The wind pressure acting on the signboard is a fluid mechanics problem involving drag forces on bluff bodies.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Analysis: This problem requires applying principles of structural analysis, including beam theory, torsion, and combined stresses.

deeper_dive_topics: Fatigue and fracture analysis of signage support structures under cyclic wind loads

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A 3 m x 1 m signboard is supported by a vertical hollow pole that is fixed to the ground. The pole has a square cross section with outer dimension 250 mm. The yield strength of the pole material is 240 MPa. To sustain a wind pressure of 7.5 kPa, the dimension d of the pole is _________ mm (round off to nearest integer). (Neglect the effect of transverse shear and load due to wind pressure acting on the pole)
